Slide of the Week

Curated by Agnes. Every Tuesday. Without fail. Since 2007. Canva tried to automate this. Agnes refused.

WEEK 894
10 PRINT "HELLO WORLD"
20 PRINT "BASIC TRAINING"
30 PRINT "MODULE 7: LOOPS"
40 FOR I = 1 TO 10
50 PRINT I; " MISSISSIPPI"
60 NEXT I
70 PRINT "END OF LESSON"
80 REM — OVERHEAD PROJECTOR
90 REM — SLIDE 14 OF 38
99 END

1974 BASIC Programming Training Manual — Slide 14/38: “Understanding the FOR/NEXT Loop”

Originally used at Honeywell corporate training, Minneapolis campus. Recovered from a dumpster behind Building C in 2011. The marker annotations are original. Whoever wrote “THIS IS WHERE I GAVE UP” in the margin—we see you.

“This slide changed my life. Not in a good way. Not in a bad way. It just… changed it.” — Agnes

The Craft

Articles, supplies, and the ongoing documentation of a dying art that refuses to die.

FEATURED ARTICLE

The Lost Art of Hand-Lettering Overhead Projector Slides

Before fonts. Before templates. Before Canva—God, especially before Canva—there was a person with a Sharpie and a transparency sheet, trying to make the word “SYNERGY” look presentable at 7:45 AM on a Monday.

That person was an artist. They didn’t know it. Their boss didn’t know it. Nobody knew it until Agnes started collecting their work in 2007 and realized: these are the cave paintings of the corporate age.

This article traces the evolution of hand-lettered OHP slides from 1962 to 1998, with over 400 examples from the archive. Featuring the legendary “Helvetica Helen” of Xerox PARC, whose slides were so beautiful they delayed three product launches because nobody could stop looking at them.

Read the full article →

EMPLOYEE SPOTLIGHT

Agnes Abernathy

Founder. Sole archivist. Technically a Canva employee since 2019. They gave her a lanyard. She has not worn it.

Agnes started ProjectorSlideStock after a dream about cheese. In the dream, a wheel of Gruyère told her that “the transparencies are dying and only you can save them.” She woke up, registered the domain, and has not stopped since.

Her former partner Bertram left for Prague in 2015 with 3,000 original hand-lettered slides. She does not discuss Bertram. The slides were recovered in 2024. Bertram was not.

Read full bio →

Our History

A timeline of persistence, loss, cheese, and overhead projectors.

2007
Founded after the cheese dream. First 200 slides catalogued in Agnes’s garage.
2011
10,000th slide uploaded. Bertram joins as co-archivist. They are happy. Briefly.
2015
Bertram leaves for Prague. Takes 3,000 slides. Agnes does not cry. (She cries.)
2019
Acquired by Canva for an undisclosed sum. Agnes stays. “They don’t understand what we are.”
2024
Bertram’s Prague collection recovered. Agnes is still here. She will always be here.

Slide Submission Guidelines

Legal

All slides are royalty-free for personal and educational use. Commercial use requires Agnes’s written permission, which she will grant after a 15-minute phone call about the history of acetate.

Canva’s legal team has asked us to stop calling this “the most important website on the internet.” We have not stopped.

“Chad Thundercock called us ‘a digital hospice for dead media.’ Thank you, Chad. That is the nicest thing anyone from Product has ever said about us.”
